trans-unit.source: Troubleshoot Azure Data Factory issues
trans-unit.target: Troubleshoot Azure Data Factory issues

trans-unit.source: Learn how to troubleshoot issues with using Azure Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to troubleshoot issues with using Azure Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshoot Data Factory issues
trans-unit.target: Troubleshoot Data Factory issues

trans-unit.source: You can troubleshoot Azure Data Factory issues using Azure Portal (or) Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You can troubleshoot Azure Data Factory issues using Azure Portal (or) Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: This topic has walkthroughs that show you how to use the Azure Portal to quickly troubleshoot errors that you encounter with Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: This topic has walkthroughs that show you how to use the Azure Portal to quickly troubleshoot errors that you encounter with Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: Problem: Not able to run Data Factory cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Problem: Not able to run Data Factory cmdlets

trans-unit.source: To resolve this issue, switch Azure mode to AzureResourceManager:
trans-unit.target: To resolve this issue, switch Azure mode to AzureResourceManager:

trans-unit.source: Launch Azure PowerShell and execute the following command to switch to the AzureResourceManager mode.The Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in the AzureResourceManager mode.
trans-unit.target: Launch Azure PowerShell and execute the following command to switch to the AzureResourceManager mode.The Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in the AzureResourceManager mode.

trans-unit.source: Problem: Unauthorized error when running a Data Factory cmdlet
trans-unit.target: Problem: Unauthorized error when running a Data Factory cmdlet

trans-unit.source: You are probably not using the right Azure account or subscription with the Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You are probably not using the right Azure account or subscription with the Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Use the following cmdlets to select the right Azure account and subscription to use with the Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Use the following cmdlets to select the right Azure account and subscription to use with the Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureAccount - Use the right user ID and password
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureAccount - Use the right user ID and password

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureSubscription - View all the subscriptions for the account.
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureSubscription - View all the subscriptions for the account.

trans-unit.source: Select-AzureSubscription <html></html> - Select the right subscription. Use the same one you use to create a data factory on the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: Select-AzureSubscription <html></html> - Select the right subscription. Use the same one you use to create a data factory on the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Problem: Fail to launch Data Gateway Express Setup from Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Problem: Fail to launch Data Gateway Express Setup from Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: The Express Setup for the Data Gateway requires Internet Explorer or a Microsoft ClickOnce compatible web browser.
trans-unit.target: The Express Setup for the Data Gateway requires Internet Explorer or a Microsoft ClickOnce compatible web browser.

trans-unit.source: If you fails to start the Express Setup, you can
trans-unit.target: If you fails to start the Express Setup, you can

trans-unit.source: Switch to Internet Explorer if you fails with other browsers.
trans-unit.target: Switch to Internet Explorer if you fails with other browsers.

trans-unit.source: Or
trans-unit.target: Or

trans-unit.source: Use the "Manual Setup" links shown on the same blade in the portal to do the installation, and then copy the Key that is provided on the screen, and paste when the Data Management Gateway configuration is ready.
trans-unit.target: Use the "Manual Setup" links shown on the same blade in the portal to do the installation, and then copy the Key that is provided on the screen, and paste when the Data Management Gateway configuration is ready.

trans-unit.source: If it doesn't launch, check your start menu for "Microsoft Data Management Gateway" and paste in the key when it launches.
trans-unit.target: If it doesn't launch, check your start menu for "Microsoft Data Management Gateway" and paste in the key when it launches.

trans-unit.source: Problem: Fail to launch Credentials Manager from Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Problem: Fail to launch Credentials Manager from Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: When set up or update a SQL Server Linked Service via Azure Portal, the Credentials Manager application will be launched to guarantee security.
trans-unit.target: When set up or update a SQL Server Linked Service via Azure Portal, the Credentials Manager application will be launched to guarantee security.

trans-unit.source: It requires Internet Explorer or a Microsoft ClickOnce compatible web browser.
trans-unit.target: It requires Internet Explorer or a Microsoft ClickOnce compatible web browser.

trans-unit.source: You can switch to Internet Explorer if you fails with other browsers.
trans-unit.target: You can switch to Internet Explorer if you fails with other browsers.

trans-unit.source: Problem: Fail to connect to on-premises SQL Server
trans-unit.target: Problem: Fail to connect to on-premises SQL Server

trans-unit.source: Verify that the SQL Server is reachable from the machine where the gateway is installed.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the SQL Server is reachable from the machine where the gateway is installed.

trans-unit.source: On the machine on which the gateway is installed, you can
trans-unit.target: On the machine on which the gateway is installed, you can

trans-unit.source: Ping the machine where the SQL Server is installed.
trans-unit.target: Ping the machine where the SQL Server is installed.

trans-unit.source: Or
trans-unit.target: Or

trans-unit.source: Try connecting to the SQL Server instance using the credentials you specified on the Azure Portal using SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS).
trans-unit.target: Try connecting to the SQL Server instance using the credentials you specified on the Azure Portal using SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS).

trans-unit.source: Problem: Input slices are in PendingExecution or PendingValidation state for ever
trans-unit.target: Problem: Input slices are in PendingExecution or PendingValidation state for ever

trans-unit.source: The slices could be in PendingExecution or PendingValidation state due to a number of reasons and one of the common reasons is that the external property is not set to true.
trans-unit.target: The slices could be in PendingExecution or PendingValidation state due to a number of reasons and one of the common reasons is that the external property is not set to true.

trans-unit.source: Any dataset that is produced outside the scope of Azure Data Factory should be marked with external property .
trans-unit.target: Any dataset that is produced outside the scope of Azure Data Factory should be marked with external property .

trans-unit.source: This indicates that the data is external and not backed by any pipelines within the data factory.
trans-unit.target: This indicates that the data is external and not backed by any pipelines within the data factory.

trans-unit.source: The data slices are marked as Ready once the data is available in the respective store.
trans-unit.target: The data slices are marked as Ready once the data is available in the respective store.

trans-unit.source: See the following example for the usage of the external property.
trans-unit.target: See the following example for the usage of the external property.

trans-unit.source: You can optionally specify externalData* when you set external to true..
trans-unit.target: You can optionally specify externalData* when you set external to true..

trans-unit.source: See Tables topic in <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference[json-scripting-reference]</linkText><title></title></link> for more details about this property.
trans-unit.target: See Tables topic in <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference[json-scripting-reference]</linkText><title></title></link> for more details about this property.

trans-unit.source: To resolve the error, add the external property and the optional externalData section to the JSON definition of the input table and recreate the table.
trans-unit.target: To resolve the error, add the external property and the optional externalData section to the JSON definition of the input table and recreate the table.

trans-unit.source: Problem: Hybrid copy operation fails
trans-unit.target: Problem: Hybrid copy operation fails

trans-unit.source: To learn more details:
trans-unit.target: To learn more details:

trans-unit.source: Launch Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager on the machine on which gateway was installed.
trans-unit.target: Launch Data Management Gateway Configuration Manager on the machine on which gateway was installed.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the Gateway name is set to the logical gateway name on the Azure Portal, Gateway key status is registered and Service status is Started.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the Gateway name is set to the logical gateway name on the Azure Portal, Gateway key status is registered and Service status is Started.

trans-unit.source: Launch Event Viewer.
trans-unit.target: Launch Event Viewer.

trans-unit.source: Expand Applications and Services Logs and click Data Management Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Expand Applications and Services Logs and click Data Management Gateway.

trans-unit.source: See if there are any errors related to Data Management Gateway.
trans-unit.target: See if there are any errors related to Data Management Gateway.

trans-unit.source: Problem: On Demand HDInsight Provisioning Fails with Error
trans-unit.target: Problem: On Demand HDInsight Provisioning Fails with Error

trans-unit.source: When using a linked service of type HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService, you should specify a linkedServiceName that points to Azure Blob Storage.
trans-unit.target: When using a linked service of type HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService, you should specify a linkedServiceName that points to Azure Blob Storage.

trans-unit.source: This storage account will be used to copy all the logs and supporting files for your on-demand HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: This storage account will be used to copy all the logs and supporting files for your on-demand HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes the activity that does the on-demand provisioning on HDInsight may fail with the following error:
trans-unit.target: Sometimes the activity that does the on-demand provisioning on HDInsight may fail with the following error:

trans-unit.source: This error usually indicates that the Location of the storage account specified in the linkedServiceName is not in the same data center location as where the HDInsight provisioning is happening.
trans-unit.target: This error usually indicates that the Location of the storage account specified in the linkedServiceName is not in the same data center location as where the HDInsight provisioning is happening.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your Azure Data Factory location is West US, and the on-demand HDInsight provisioning happens in West US, but the Azure blob storage account location is set to East US, the on-demand provisioning will fail.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your Azure Data Factory location is West US, and the on-demand HDInsight provisioning happens in West US, but the Azure blob storage account location is set to East US, the on-demand provisioning will fail.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, there is a second JSON property additionalLinkedServiceNames where additional storage accounts may be specified in on-demand HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, there is a second JSON property additionalLinkedServiceNames where additional storage accounts may be specified in on-demand HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Those additional linked storage accounts should be in the same location as the HDInsight cluster, or it will fail with the same error.
trans-unit.target: Those additional linked storage accounts should be in the same location as the HDInsight cluster, or it will fail with the same error.

trans-unit.source: Problem: Custom Activity Fails
trans-unit.target: Problem: Custom Activity Fails

trans-unit.source: When using a Custom Activity in Azure Data Factory (pipeline activity type CustomActivity), the custom application runs in the specified linked service to HDInsight as a Map only streaming MapReduce job.
trans-unit.target: When using a Custom Activity in Azure Data Factory (pipeline activity type CustomActivity), the custom application runs in the specified linked service to HDInsight as a Map only streaming MapReduce job.

trans-unit.source: When the custom activity runs, Azure Data Factory will be able to capture that output from the HDInsight cluster, and save it in the adfjobs storage container in your Azure Blob Storage account.
trans-unit.target: When the custom activity runs, Azure Data Factory will be able to capture that output from the HDInsight cluster, and save it in the adfjobs storage container in your Azure Blob Storage account.

trans-unit.source: In case of an error, you can read the text from stderr output text file after a failure has occurred.
trans-unit.target: In case of an error, you can read the text from stderr output text file after a failure has occurred.

trans-unit.source: The files are accessible and readable from the Azure portal itself in the web browser, or by using storage explorer tools to access the files kept in the storage container in Azure Blob Storage directly.
trans-unit.target: The files are accessible and readable from the Azure portal itself in the web browser, or by using storage explorer tools to access the files kept in the storage container in Azure Blob Storage directly.

trans-unit.source: To enumerate and read the logs for a particular Custom Activity, you may follow one of the illustrated walkthroughs later on this page.
trans-unit.target: To enumerate and read the logs for a particular Custom Activity, you may follow one of the illustrated walkthroughs later on this page.

trans-unit.source: In summary:
trans-unit.target: In summary:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal Browse to locate your Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal Browse to locate your Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: Use the Diagram button to view the data factory diagram, and click on the Dataset Table that follows the specific Pipeline which has the Custom Activity.
trans-unit.target: Use the Diagram button to view the data factory diagram, and click on the Dataset Table that follows the specific Pipeline which has the Custom Activity.

trans-unit.source: In the Table blade, Click on the slice of interest in the Problem slices for the time frame to be investigated.
trans-unit.target: In the Table blade, Click on the slice of interest in the Problem slices for the time frame to be investigated.

trans-unit.source: The detailed Data Slice blade will appear and it can list multiple Activity runs for the slice.
trans-unit.target: The detailed Data Slice blade will appear and it can list multiple Activity runs for the slice.

trans-unit.source: Click on an Activity from the list.
trans-unit.target: Click on an Activity from the list.

trans-unit.source: The Activity Run Details blade will appear.
trans-unit.target: The Activity Run Details blade will appear.

trans-unit.source: It will list the Error Message in the middle of the blade, and several Log files listed at the bottom of the blade affiliated with that activity run.
trans-unit.target: It will list the Error Message in the middle of the blade, and several Log files listed at the bottom of the blade affiliated with that activity run.

trans-unit.source: Logs/system-0.log
trans-unit.target: Logs/system-0.log

trans-unit.source: Status
trans-unit.target: Status

trans-unit.source: Status/exit
trans-unit.target: Status/exit

trans-unit.source: Status/stderr
trans-unit.target: Status/stderr

trans-unit.source: Status/stdout
trans-unit.target: Status/stdout

trans-unit.source: Click on the first Log file item in the list, and the log will open in a new blade with the full text displayed for you to read.
trans-unit.target: Click on the first Log file item in the list, and the log will open in a new blade with the full text displayed for you to read.

trans-unit.source: Review the text of each log by clicking on each one.
trans-unit.target: Review the text of each log by clicking on each one.

trans-unit.source: The text viewer blade will open.
trans-unit.target: The text viewer blade will open.

trans-unit.source: You can click the Download button to download the text file for optional offline viewing.
trans-unit.target: You can click the Download button to download the text file for optional offline viewing.

trans-unit.source: One common error from a custom activity is
trans-unit.target: One common error from a custom activity is

trans-unit.source: Package execution failed with exit code '1'. See 'wasb://adfjobs@storageaccount.blob.core.windows.net/PackageJobs/<html></html>/<html></html>/Status/stderr' for more details.
trans-unit.target: Package execution failed with exit code '1'. See 'wasb://adfjobs@storageaccount.blob.core.windows.net/PackageJobs/<html></html>/<html></html>/Status/stderr' for more details.

trans-unit.source: To see more details for this kind of error, open the stderr file.
trans-unit.target: To see more details for this kind of error, open the stderr file.

trans-unit.source: One common error seen there is a timeout condition such as this:
trans-unit.target: One common error seen there is a timeout condition such as this:

trans-unit.source: INFO mapreduce.Job: Task Id : attempt_1424212573646_0168_m_000000_0, Status : FAILED
trans-unit.target: INFO mapreduce.Job: Task Id : attempt_1424212573646_0168_m_000000_0, Status : FAILED

trans-unit.source: AttemptID:attempt_1424212573646_0168_m_000000_0 Timed out after 600 secs
trans-unit.target: AttemptID:attempt_1424212573646_0168_m_000000_0 Timed out after 600 secs

trans-unit.source: This same error may appear multiple times, if the job has retried 3 times for example, over the span of 30 or more minutes.
trans-unit.target: This same error may appear multiple times, if the job has retried 3 times for example, over the span of 30 or more minutes.

trans-unit.source: This time out error indicates a 600 second (10 minute) timeout has happened.
trans-unit.target: This time out error indicates a 600 second (10 minute) timeout has happened.

trans-unit.source: Typically this means the custom .Net application has not issued any status update for 10 minutes.
trans-unit.target: Typically this means the custom .Net application has not issued any status update for 10 minutes.

trans-unit.source: If the application is hanging or stalled waiting on something for too long, the 10 minute timeout is a safety mechanism to prevent it from waiting forever and delaying your Azure Data Factory pipeline.
trans-unit.target: If the application is hanging or stalled waiting on something for too long, the 10 minute timeout is a safety mechanism to prevent it from waiting forever and delaying your Azure Data Factory pipeline.

trans-unit.source: This time out originates in the configuration of HDInsight cluster that is linked in the custom activity.
trans-unit.target: This time out originates in the configuration of HDInsight cluster that is linked in the custom activity.

trans-unit.source: The setting is mapred.task.timeout, which defaults to 600000 milliseconds, as documented in the Apache default settings here: http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.4.0/hadoop-mapreduce-client/hadoop-mapreduce-client-core/mapred-default.xml
trans-unit.target: The setting is mapred.task.timeout, which defaults to 600000 milliseconds, as documented in the Apache default settings here: http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.4.0/hadoop-mapreduce-client/hadoop-mapreduce-client-core/mapred-default.xml

trans-unit.source: You can overide this default by changing the defaults at the time of provisioning your HDInsight provisioning cluster.
trans-unit.target: You can overide this default by changing the defaults at the time of provisioning your HDInsight provisioning cluster.

trans-unit.source: When using Azure Data Factory and HDInsight On-demand linked service, the JSON property can be added near your HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: When using Azure Data Factory and HDInsight On-demand linked service, the JSON property can be added near your HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can increase the value to 20 minutes using this JSON property.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can increase the value to 20 minutes using this JSON property.

trans-unit.source: For more context and a full example of the JSON to edit these map reduce Configuration properties see Example #3 in the MSDN documentation here https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn893526.aspx
trans-unit.target: For more context and a full example of the JSON to edit these map reduce Configuration properties see Example #3 in the MSDN documentation here https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn893526.aspx

trans-unit.source: Problem: PowerShell request fails with error error 400 Bad Request "No registered resource provider found..."
trans-unit.target: Problem: PowerShell request fails with error error 400 Bad Request "No registered resource provider found..."

trans-unit.source: As of March 10, 2015, the Azure Data Factory PowerShell early private preview versions 2014-05-01-preview, 2014-07-01-preview, and 2014-08-01-preview will be discontinued. We recommend that you use the latest version of the ADF cmdlets, which are now part of the Azure PowerShell Download, such as the download from this URL http://go.microsoft.com/?linkid=9811175&clcid=0x409
trans-unit.target: As of March 10, 2015, the Azure Data Factory PowerShell early private preview versions 2014-05-01-preview, 2014-07-01-preview, and 2014-08-01-preview will be discontinued. We recommend that you use the latest version of the ADF cmdlets, which are now part of the Azure PowerShell Download, such as the download from this URL http://go.microsoft.com/?linkid=9811175&clcid=0x409

trans-unit.source: If you use the discontinued versions of the Azure PowerShell SDK you may receive the following errors:
trans-unit.target: If you use the discontinued versions of the Azure PowerShell SDK you may receive the following errors:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> Walkthrough: Troubleshooting an error with copying data
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> Walkthrough: Troubleshooting an error with copying data

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, you will introduce an error in the tutorial from Get started with Data Factory article and learn how you can use Azure Portal to troubleshoot the error.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, you will introduce an error in the tutorial from Get started with Data Factory article and learn how you can use Azure Portal to troubleshoot the error.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Complete the Tutorial in the <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Data Factory[adfgetstarted]</linkText><title></title></link> article.
trans-unit.target: Complete the Tutorial in the <link><linkText>Get started with Azure Data Factory[adfgetstarted]</linkText><title></title></link> article.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that the ADFTutorialDataFactory produces data in the emp table in the Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that the ADFTutorialDataFactory produces data in the emp table in the Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Now, delete the emp table (drop table emp) from the Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Now, delete the emp table (drop table emp) from the Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: This will introduce an error.
trans-unit.target: This will introduce an error.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command in the Azure PowerShell to update the active period for the pipeline so that it tries to write data to the emp table, which doesn’t exist anymore.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command in the Azure PowerShell to update the active period for the pipeline so that it tries to write data to the emp table, which doesn’t exist anymore.

trans-unit.source: Replace StartDateTime value with the current day and EndDateTime value with the next day.
trans-unit.target: Replace StartDateTime value with the current day and EndDateTime value with the next day.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure Preview Portal to troubleshoot the error
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Preview Portal to troubleshoot the error

trans-unit.source: Login to <link><linkText>Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Login to <link><linkText>Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click ADFTutorialDataFactory from the Startboard.
trans-unit.target: Click ADFTutorialDataFactory from the Startboard.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t see the data factory link on the Startboard, click BROWSE hub and click Everything.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t see the data factory link on the Startboard, click BROWSE hub and click Everything.

trans-unit.source: Click Data factories… in the Browse blade, and click ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: Click Data factories… in the Browse blade, and click ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: Notice that you see With errors on the Datasets tile.
trans-unit.target: Notice that you see With errors on the Datasets tile.

trans-unit.source: Click With errors.
trans-unit.target: Click With errors.

trans-unit.source: You should see Datasets with errors blade.
trans-unit.target: You should see Datasets with errors blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory with Errors link</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory with Errors link</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Datasets with errors blade, click EmpSQLTable to see the TABLE blade.
trans-unit.target: In the Datasets with errors blade, click EmpSQLTable to see the TABLE blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Datasets with errors blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Datasets with errors blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the TABLE blade, you should see the problem slices, i.e., slices with an error in the Problem slices list at the bottom.
trans-unit.target: In the TABLE blade, you should see the problem slices, i.e., slices with an error in the Problem slices list at the bottom.

trans-unit.source: You can also see any recent slices with errors in the Recent slices list.
trans-unit.target: You can also see any recent slices with errors in the Recent slices list.

trans-unit.source: Click on a slice in the Problem slices list.
trans-unit.target: Click on a slice in the Problem slices list.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Table blade with problem slices</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Table blade with problem slices</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you click Problem slices (not on a specific problem), you will see the DATA SLICES blade and then click a specific problem slice to see the DATA SLICE slide for the selected data slice.
trans-unit.target: If you click Problem slices (not on a specific problem), you will see the DATA SLICES blade and then click a specific problem slice to see the DATA SLICE slide for the selected data slice.

trans-unit.source: In the DATA SLICE blade for EmpSQLTable, you see all activity runs for the slice in the list at the bottom.
trans-unit.target: In the DATA SLICE blade for EmpSQLTable, you see all activity runs for the slice in the list at the bottom.

trans-unit.source: Click on an activity run from the list that failed.
trans-unit.target: Click on an activity run from the list that failed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Slice blade with active runs</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Slice blade with active runs</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Activity Run Details blade for the activity run you selected, you should see details about the error.
trans-unit.target: In the Activity Run Details blade for the activity run you selected, you should see details about the error.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you see: Invalid object name ‘emp’.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you see: Invalid object name ‘emp’.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Activity run details with an error</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Activity run details with an error</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To resolve this issue, create the emp table using the SQL script from Get started with Data Factory[adfgetstarted] article.
trans-unit.target: To resolve this issue, create the emp table using the SQL script from Get started with Data Factory[adfgetstarted] article.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure PowerShell cmdlets to troubleshoot the error
trans-unit.target: Use Azure PowerShell cmdlets to troubleshoot the error

trans-unit.source: Launch Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Launch Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Switch to AzureResourceManager mode as the Data Factory cmdlets are available only in this mode.
trans-unit.target: Switch to AzureResourceManager mode as the Data Factory cmdlets are available only in this mode.

trans-unit.source: Run Get-AzureDataFactorySlice command to see the slices and their statuses.
trans-unit.target: Run Get-AzureDataFactorySlice command to see the slices and their statuses.

trans-unit.source: You should see a slice with the status: Failed.
trans-unit.target: You should see a slice with the status: Failed.

trans-unit.source: Replace StartDateTime with the StartDateTime value you specified for the Set-AzureDataFactoryPipelineActivePeriod.
trans-unit.target: Replace StartDateTime with the StartDateTime value you specified for the Set-AzureDataFactoryPipelineActivePeriod.

trans-unit.source: Note the Start time for the problem slice (the slice with Status set to Failed) in the output.
trans-unit.target: Note the Start time for the problem slice (the slice with Status set to Failed) in the output.

trans-unit.source: Now, run the Get-AzureDataFactoryRun cmdlet to get details about activity run for the slice.
trans-unit.target: Now, run the Get-AzureDataFactoryRun cmdlet to get details about activity run for the slice.

trans-unit.source: The value of StartDateTime is the Start time for the error/problem slice you noted from the previous step.
trans-unit.target: The value of StartDateTime is the Start time for the error/problem slice you noted from the previous step.

trans-unit.source: The date-time should be enclosed in double quotes.
trans-unit.target: The date-time should be enclosed in double quotes.

trans-unit.source: You should see the output with details about the error (similar to the following):
trans-unit.target: You should see the output with details about the error (similar to the following):

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> Walkthrough: Troubleshooting an error with Hive/Pig processing
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> Walkthrough: Troubleshooting an error with Hive/Pig processing

trans-unit.source: This walkthrough provides steps to troubleshoot an error with Hive/Pig processing by using both Azure Preview Portal and Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This walkthrough provides steps to troubleshoot an error with Hive/Pig processing by using both Azure Preview Portal and Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Walkthrough: Use Azure Portal to troubleshoot an error with Pig/Hive processing
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough: Use Azure Portal to troubleshoot an error with Pig/Hive processing

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, data set is in an error state due to a failure in Hive processing on an HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, data set is in an error state due to a failure in Hive processing on an HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Click With errors on Datasets tile on the DATA FACTORY home page.
trans-unit.target: Click With errors on Datasets tile on the DATA FACTORY home page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>With errors link on Datasets tile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>With errors link on Datasets tile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Datasets with errors blade, click the table that you are interested in.
trans-unit.target: In the Datasets with errors blade, click the table that you are interested in.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Datasets with errors blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Datasets with errors blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the TABLE blade, Click on the problem slice with STATUS set to Failed.
trans-unit.target: In the TABLE blade, Click on the problem slice with STATUS set to Failed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Table with problem slices</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Table with problem slices</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the DATA SLICE blade, click the Activity Run that failed.
trans-unit.target: In the DATA SLICE blade, click the Activity Run that failed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data slice with failed runs</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data slice with failed runs</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS blade, you can download the files associated with the HDInsight processing.
trans-unit.target: In the ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS blade, you can download the files associated with the HDInsight processing.

trans-unit.source: Click Download for Status/stderr to download the error log file that contains details about the error.
trans-unit.target: Click Download for Status/stderr to download the error log file that contains details about the error.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Activity run details with download link</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Activity run details with download link</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Walkthrough: Use Azure PowerShell to troubleshoot an error with Pig/Hive processing
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough: Use Azure PowerShell to troubleshoot an error with Pig/Hive processing

trans-unit.source: Launch Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Launch Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Switch to AzureResourceManager mode as the Data Factory cmdlets are available only in this mode.
trans-unit.target: Switch to AzureResourceManager mode as the Data Factory cmdlets are available only in this mode.

trans-unit.source: Run Get-AzureDataFactorySlice command to see the slices and their statuses.
trans-unit.target: Run Get-AzureDataFactorySlice command to see the slices and their statuses.

trans-unit.source: You should see a slice with the status: Failed.
trans-unit.target: You should see a slice with the status: Failed.

trans-unit.source: Replace StartDateTime with the StartDateTime value you specified for the Set-AzureDataFactoryPipelineActivePeriod.
trans-unit.target: Replace StartDateTime with the StartDateTime value you specified for the Set-AzureDataFactoryPipelineActivePeriod.

trans-unit.source: Note the Start time for the problem slice (the slice with Status set to Failed) in the output.
trans-unit.target: Note the Start time for the problem slice (the slice with Status set to Failed) in the output.

trans-unit.source: Now, run the Get-AzureDataFactoryRun cmdlet to get details about activity run for the slice.
trans-unit.target: Now, run the Get-AzureDataFactoryRun cmdlet to get details about activity run for the slice.

trans-unit.source: The value of StartDateTime is the Start time for the error/problem slice you noted from the previous step.
trans-unit.target: The value of StartDateTime is the Start time for the error/problem slice you noted from the previous step.

trans-unit.source: The date-time should be enclosed in double quotes.
trans-unit.target: The date-time should be enclosed in double quotes.

trans-unit.source: You should see the output with details about the error (similar to the following):
trans-unit.target: You should see the output with details about the error (similar to the following):

trans-unit.source: You can run Save-AzureDataFactoryLog cmdlet with Id value you see from the above output and download the log files using the -DownloadLogs option for the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can run Save-AzureDataFactoryLog cmdlet with Id value you see from the above output and download the log files using the -DownloadLogs option for the cmdlet.
